name: First Issue
short: We are creating a web-application to provide reliable access to a database for BC's industrial greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions data.  This interface will initially work with an existing database and industrial reporting system. Over time, the project may extend to database improvements or other parts of BCâ€™s GHG data system. We are looking for a collaborative team, ready to learn, and passionate about providing solutions that will contribute to reducing industrial GHG emissions in BC and improving reporting to the public about our progress to our GHG targets.
description:
Large industrial operations in BC have been required to report their GHG emissions and related data to the Province since 2010. CleanBC sets out the next phase of actions that will move BC toward meeting legislated greenhouse gas (GHG) targets, including an Industrial Incentive Program that rewards industrial operations for moving toward world leading emissions benchmarks and a Clean Industry Fund that invests in emission reduction projects for industry. These programs require expanded capabilities to store, sort, check, and analyze industrial GHG data. The system we build may also be used to administer CleanBC for Industry programs, and track program outcomes.  Improving access for policy makers to BC's wealth of  data about industrial GHGs and the processes that drive them will help identify emissions reduction opportunities and measure the outcomes of our GHG reduction efforts in a timely way.

The project team will create a web-based interface that will replace the public excel-based Industrial Facility GHG Emissions Report. It will also expand the range of accessible data available for authorized internal government policy needs. The Product will be open source, using flexible technologies, and interoperable. This Product will also  need to adhere to the framework outlined in the Greenhouse Gas Emissions Reporting Regulation and operate within a context of several related datasets within the BC government. This project will greatly expand the user base for BC’s industrial GHG data, and so will need to include a simple and searchable web interface capable of meeting the different data viewing needs across a range of stakeholders.

The Product is anticipated to include:

  1. A searchable web interface to replace government's current system of public reporting of emissions from industrial operations;
  2. Ability to access all available information reported under the Greenhouse Gas Emission Reporting Regulation and WCI methodology for authorized internal government policy needs;
  3. Analytical and visualization tools (e.g. applying set formulae to the data or producing graphics);
  4. Tools to assist government to test for compliance with the Regulation and check data quality;
  5. Administrative supports for the CleanBC Program for Industry (e.g. managing program applications, eligibility calculations, result tracking);
  6. Possible database improvements (currently in Oracle, but open to other database solutions) and optimization of/additions to industrial reporting inputs;
  7. Options to link to or harmonize with other related systems (e.g. Provincial GHG Inventory, Carbon Neutral Government); 
  8. Diagnostic review of data flows throughout the system to ensure the integrity of data transfers;  
  9. Support for the creation of a complex data model that connects various components of GHG quantification and reporting.  Examples include: process diagrams, third party GHG verification reports, spatial data, financial tracking, compliance actions and status, and data fields contingent on different methodology choices; and,
  10. Controls to ensure that confidential information is only accessed and used in compliance with applicable legislation.

Ideally, the successful team will include a data wrangler, an experienced database architect and/or a technical architect with a skillset that can transition to meet the development needs beyond the Inception and Proof of Concept phases. 

We are seeking new ideas and emerging technologies to improve the applications that support industrial GHG management in BC. We anticipate that, throughout the inception and proof of concept phases, we will further refine the scope and feature needs of the Product using a design focus and user research.  As the project continues, other areas of need relating to GHG data may be identified and included.

Evaluation Schedule for the Competition

            January 25th  - We will notify all applicants whether they are shortlisted

            January 29th - 31st - Code Challenge

            February 4th – 6th - Team Scenario

            January 7th - We will notify all companies

teamQuestions.question: How does your team approach working and communicating with less technical team members and subject matter experts?
teamQuestions.guideline:
What is your team's approach to:

- dealing with miscommunication,

- ensuring that your team understands the problem area as the business sees it, and

- translating technical solutions into plain language?

teamQuestions.question: What tools, processes and relationships does your team use to ensure continuous improvements, quality assurance and user acceptance?
teamQuestions.guideline:
How does your team: 

- assure checks and balances are built into your workflow,

- conduct peer-review on the work done, and

- ensure that you've met user needs?

teamQuestions.question: How does your team approach the development of user stories (e.g., determining the ‘definition of done’ and assigning story points)?
teamQuestions.guideline:
How does your team:

- create a persona,

- decide upon the steps needed to complete a task, and,

- prioritize workflow?

teamQuestions.question: How does your team approach the audit of existing data sources in various formats and optimise them for downstream purposes such as analytics?
teamQuestions.guideline: How does your team develop solutions to complex data problems?

teamQuestions.question: How is the combination of the skills and experience of your team relevant to this opportunity?
What defines a "high-performing" Scrum team?  What metrics does your team use to measure its own performance?  How do ensure that these metrics are accurate?
teamQuestions.guideline: How does your team conduct sprint planning and retrospectives?

addenda.description: December 21, 2018: Please note, the notification email for this opportunity incorrectly identified the closing date as January 24, 2019. The correct date is as identified on the opportunity page.

name: Second Issue
short: The K â€“ 12 Next Generation Network (K12NGN) is a large network providing connectivity and security services to over 1,600 BC public schools grouped in 60 school districts with over 20 contracts. The delivery of the services is carried out through a group of vendors that are contracted by the Province. The K12NGN Team, through mostly manual processes, manages the service requests, ordering changes and incidents for all the public schools.
description:
December 21, 2018: This opportunities closing time has been reduced to January 14, 2019.

Since 2017, the Next Generation Network(NGN) has delivered quality network services that include WAN, internet and security to over 1600 schools across the 60 school districts.  Key business processes such as service requests and ordering, managing changes and incidents have been developed and implemented to support the delivery of these key services.  Today, the service delivery of NGN is carried out manually using basic productivity tools (Words, Outlook, Excel) with a small staff of 3, and district information for the 1600+ NGN sites is managed on a single spreadsheet on SharePoint and shared among the 3 staff.

Impetus for the Project 

CRM2011 was the application used for the legacy education network (PLNET), which is no longer supported.  This legacy application does not adequately capture the business needs of the new K12NGN and needs to be replaced. 

Objectives

The Ministry of Education is looking for a team to help meet the following objectives: 

1. Implement NGN business management processes in MS Dynamics

2. Integrates multiple school and vendor data sources into a structured and coherent data set.

Please check out our product backlog for an understanding of the Epics and User Stories that describe the NGN business and this diagram for an understanding of our technical constraints we’ll need your team to work within should your company be the successful proponent.

What We Need

We are looking for a team that is certified on MS Dynamics product solutions with strong capabilities in modern web application development that can work with the Ministry beyond the delivery of a minimum viable product. 

• We’re looking for a team experienced with:

* Configuration of Microsoft Dynamics using out-of-the box features

* Agile/Scrum

* Test Driven Development

* Developing web applications that manage contracts and payments

* Developing APIs  

Who You’ll Be Working With

We will provide the following resources on the government side to work with you:

• A Product Owner who is a subject matter expert in the NGN business

• Our Ministry Application Architect

• Other subject matter experts as needed

Evaluation Schedule for the Competition

This schedule could change, but our intention is to complete the competition and evaluation on this opportunity by the following schedule:

 January 14th – We will notify all applicants whether you are shortlisted

 

 If your company is shortlisted, your team will be invited to participate in the following activities:

This schedule could change, but our intention is to complete the competition and evaluation on this opportunity by the following schedule:

 January 15th – We will notify all applicants whether you are shortlisted

 If your company is shortlisted, your team will be invited to participate in the following activities:

Jan 16 - 18th – Code Challenge

Jan 22nd – 24th Team Scenario

Jan 25th – We will notify all companies of our decision and announce the winning company

About the Budget and Phases of Work

Budget

The Total Proponent Cost set out in the Proponent’s Proposal must not exceed $250,000 CAD (inclusive of all expenses but exclusive of applicable taxes). Proponents will not be permitted to submit a Proposal unless this mandatory requirement is satisfied.

Phases of Work

Inception phase (1 week)

We will work together to:

• clearly define and align around our objectives

• scope a backlog of what we think can be delivered by the end of the Proof of Concept phase, and

• set up the technical environment in which you’ll deliver the product.

Proof of Concept phase (4 weeks)

For 2 sprints you will deliver on the backlog that we scoped in the Inception, culminating in an Alpha release.

Implementation phase (6 weeks)

 

If we decide to continue the project past the Proof of Concept phase, and the budget for this phase is approved, you’ll continue to deliver on the highest priority items in the product backlog.

teamQuestions.question: What experience does your company have with Microsoft Dynamics?
teamQuestions.guideline:
Please include the following in your response:

  • Description of projects
  • Duration of projects
  • Are the resulting applications still in use?
  • What was the relative use of system configuration versus custom development (by percentage)?

teamQuestions.question: We anticipate that this opportunity will require you to create one or more APIs.  How does your company design and implement APIs?

We anticipate that this opportunity will require you to create several new business workflows (please refer to this opportunity's road map).  How does your company design and implement new business workflows?
Describe your experience developing and presenting operational dashboards
